title: "Gloves are off" with UK parliament voting to release Andrew documents | The World | ABC NEWS
description: UK Parliament has voted to release documents relating to former Prince Andrew's appointment as trade envoy between 2001 and 2011.   Cultural historian Dr Cindy McCreery says it shows Britain has entered a new era of "transparency and accountability" with the Royal family.   British MPs broke parliamentary convention to criticise the former prince, who was arrested last week on suspicion of misconduct in public office amid claims he shared confidential government information with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.   Dr McCreery told The World's Yvonne Yong that Westminster was "open slather" against Andrew. title: Japan's snow shovellers battle it out to become champion | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Japan's Yamagata prefecture has held an annual snow shovelling competition, with hundreds of participants from around the country. It's called the "jimendashi" contest, which roughly translates to "dig out the first spring". title: Australian diplomats advised to leave Middle East amid US-Iran tensions | ABC NEWS
description: The Australian government is offering to evacuate diplomats and their families from the Middle East as fears of US strikes on Iran loom large.  Australian residents in Lebanon and Israel are being urged to leave while commercial flights are still available, while the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is warning Australian citizens to reconsider their need to travel to the region.  US President Donald Trump issued a vague threat against Iran in his State of the Union address, ahead of talks between Washington and Tehran officials for a nuclear deal. title: NSW flags tougher laws following violent homophobic attacks linked to IS | ABC NEWS
description: NSW Premier Chris Minns has floated tougher laws on gay hate crimes after the ABC released a report on homophobic attacks inspired by Islamic State in Sydney.  Videos emerged of gay and bisexual teens being bashed and robbed in Sydney after being baited on dating apps.  Some of the alleged attackers have links to the terror group which produced the Bondi Beach gunmen Naveed and Sajid Akram. title: Trump’s theatrics at the State of the Union | ABC News Daily podcast
description: US President Donald Trump spent almost two hours outlining what he believes to be a myriad of achievements on the economy and immigration.    It’s the longest State of the Union address ever recorded.     But has the US president convinced voters that his first year in office has been a raging success and can he turn his tanking popularity around before the mid-term elections in November.     Today, Emma Shortis, a US politics expert at the progressive think tank, the Australia Institute, on Trump’s State of the Union address.     Featured:    Emma Shortis, Director of the Australia Institute's International & Security Affairs Program

title: Two men to face court over alleged abduction  and murder of Chris Baghsarian | ABC NEWS
description: Two men charged over the alleged kidnapping and murder of Sydney grandfather Chris Baghsarian will face court after being arrested in Sydney’s northwest. The 85-year-old was abducted from his home in what police say was a case of mistaken identity. title: Australian children in Syrian camp tell the ABC they want to come home | ABC NEWS
description: The ABC has gained access to Al-Roj camp in north-eastern Syria and spoken to some of the 23 children who made a failed attempt to leave last week.  One of the youngest Australians in a camp for the families of killed and captured Islamic State fighters in northeastern Syria has told the ABC she just wants to get home to Australia. title: Labor hints at changes to capital gains tax | ABC NEWS
description: The federal government is considering changes to the capital gains tax ahead of the May budget. Capital gains taxes are paid on profits from disposing assets like investments, property, shares and crypto. RN Breakfast political reporter Tom Crowley takes a closer look at what might happen and who'd be affected most. title: US and Iran know a war would be "costly, long, and bloody" | ABC NEWS
description: The US has imposed a new swathe of sanctions against Iran as anxiety grows over the prospect of war between Washington and Tehran despite upcoming talks for a nuclear deal. The Australian government has advised its diplomatic staff and their families to evacuate from the Middle East as a precaution.  The Australian National University’s Dr Alam Saleh says 'war could happen anytime' and Australian authorities are taking the threat seriously. title: Central Australia sees 600mm of rain in 48 hours | ABC NEWS
description: Heavy rain across large parts of the Barkly and Central Australia has closed roads and inundated cattle stations.  Situated in the eastern central region of the Northern Territory, The Barkly Region is the second largest Local Government Area in Australia and the fourth largest in the world. Sid Vashist Mayor of Barkly Regional council says his region has not had a functioning Bureau of Meteorology weather radar for over a decade, limiting access to real time data. title: Australia's most successful winter Olympics team returns home | ABC NEWS
description: Olympians have arrived back in Australia following their most successful Winter Games ever. Australia won 3 golds, two silvers and a bronze at the Milano Cortina games.  Closing ceremony flag-bearers Gold medal moguls champion Cooper Woods and aerials silver medallist Danielle Scott spoke to ABC News about Australia’s success at the Games.
